title: 112_s922
content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011'' and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, high school dropouts cost the nation billions in lost wages, and urban high school graduation rates are below the national average. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime compared to graduates. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime compared to graduates. Increasing the high school completion rate could save the United States billions annually in reduced crime costs. A 10-percent increase in the male high school graduation rate could lead to significant reductions in arrest rates for various crimes. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration and prepare them for employment or education leading to employment. The Act aims to reduce disproportionate youth incarceration, especially among minority youth, by providing job training, education, and support services to prepare them for economic self-sufficiency and advancement. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for out-of-school youth and those involved in the criminal justice system in urban areas, offering holistic services to prepare them for employment or education leading to employment, and to reduce disproportionate youth incarceration. It also defines a community-based affiliate as an organization affiliated with a national intermediary. The section defines key terms such as "community-based affiliate" as a community organization affiliated with a national intermediary, "eligible youth" as individuals aged 18-24 not in school or involved in the criminal justice system, and "national intermediary" as a nonprofit organization with expertise in serving youth in urban areas. The Urban Jobs Program grants aim to provide comprehensive services to eligible youth in urban communities, offering pathways to employment or education leading to employment. The program targets individuals aged 18-24 who are not in school or involved in criminal behavior, operating in 25 states for over 20 years. Recidivism is defined as a tendency to return to criminal behavior, and an unsubsidized job is one that pays wages without public funding. To be eligible for a grant under the Urban Jobs Program, a national intermediary must submit an application with specified information to the Secretary. The application must include a grant request, proposed uses of funds, and goals for participants, such as increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, and increased attainment of unsubsidized jobs. The curr_chunk describes the outcomes expected from the program, including reduced recidivism, increased high school diploma attainment, improved literacy and numeracy, and attainment of industry-recognized certificates. It also mentions the importance of community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and understanding of youth characteristics in supporting the program. The program aims to enable participants to create caring relationships, set goals for employment or education, and participate in various activities. The program aims to enable participants to develop workplace skills, critical thinking, and collaboration, as well as a sense of responsibility for their future. It also focuses on reducing risk-taking behaviors and improving educational outcomes. The Urban Jobs Program aims to improve educational outcomes, employment prospects, and reduce recidivism through activities leading to industry-recognized certificates. Eligible activities include case management to help participants navigate the program. The Urban Jobs Program offers case management, educational services like skill assessment and preparation for high school equivalency, employment and job readiness activities such as internships and occupational skills training, and support services including health and nutrition. The Urban Jobs Program provides training, personal development, unsubsidized jobs, support services like health and nutrition, substance abuse counseling, housing assistance, and transportation. Reports on program progress are submitted annually to relevant committees. The Urban Jobs Program progress report includes details on establishing programs through national intermediaries and the establishment of the National Jobs Council Advisory Committee with 11 members appointed by the Secretary of Labor. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary of Labor, including representatives from employers in high-growth industries, a national intermediary staff member, and Department of Labor representatives. The Committee's duties involve analyzing and making recommendations on program design, strategic priorities, and guidelines for program activities. Members serve for the life of the Committee, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee prepares periodic reports with recommendations on program activities and guidelines. Committee members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses while performing services. The Secretary may accept voluntary services from Committee members without compensation. Federal employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Committee is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Congress recommends establishing local jobs council advisory committees with at least 1/3 of members being employers in high-impact industries. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 is amended to authorize funding for Urban Jobs Programs, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 2012 to 2016. Additionally, the establishment of local jobs council advisory committees with a requirement for at least 1/3 of members to be employers in high-impact industries is recommended.
